November 28, l?£l
Mr. Seymour Siegel
Director, WNYC
Municipal Building
Chambers Street
New York, New York
Dear Syt
If this letter gets by with less than four pages I will be surprised.
However, I did want to write you my opinions on various matters and
report on others before seeing you next weekend.
In response to your letter of November 20, I have been working on the
school problem. I will take part in a panel set up by George Jennings
during the SBC next week. I had planned to go to Cleveland to confer
with Bill Levenson this week; that was not possible. We are giving it
much thought, and I am sure will evolve a plan which the school stations
will buy. Incidentally, I am enclosing a list of those who have ac¬
cepted Packages 3 and U, knowing that they will have to make contri¬
butions to the Network after January 1. You will note that a good
many of the school stations are included.
Regarding the fourth paragraphs in the November 20 letter regarding
Board Meetings, I have done considerable sole searching, as well as
file searching and come up with the follow ng:
In the budget approved at the September New York meeting, there was
a $2,000 item for Kellogg Board Meetings. This was in the amount of
$2,000, $1,1*00 of which has already been spent. Second, in the
minutes of the June Allertgn Board Meeting, I would like to call your
attention to Page 2, Item%; to Pare 1*, Items 1 through 5>; and to
Appendix A, Page h, Item 3* All of these, I believe, point to the
fact that we should have quarterly meetings of a small Executive
Kellogg Committee for the purpose of implementing the Kellogg grant.
My notes indicate that we agreed in principle at Bilox/to the fact
that this Board could just as well be regionally centered close to
Illinois so that travel expenses might be kept to a minimum. Need¬
less to say, the NAKB Board can meet at your call, but I would be
remiss in my duty if I did not strongly object to paying for such
meetings from Kellogg Funds. I feel that this would put the entire
project in jeopardy and mi$it very well prevent us from securing the
grants already promised for ensuing years.
